user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Unlock_Global:
```c
void OS_Unlock_Global(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_objtype_state_t *objtype;

    if (token->obj_type < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER && token->lock_mode != OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        objtype = &OS_objtype_state[token->obj_type];

        /*
         * Un-track ownership of this table.  It should only be owned by one
         * task at a time, and this aids in recovery if the owning task is
         * deleted or experiences an exception causing it to not be freed.
         *
         * This is done before unlocking, while this has exclusive access
         * to the state object.
         */
        if ((objtype->owner_key.key_value & 0xFF000000) != OS_LOCK_KEY_FIXED_VALUE ||
            objtype->owner_key.key_value != token->lock_key.key_value)
        {
            /* this is almost certainly a bug */
            OS_DEBUG("ERROR: global %u released using mismatched key=0x%lx expected=0x%lx\n",
                     (unsigned int)token->obj_type, (unsigned long)token->lock_key.key_value,
                     (unsigned long)objtype->owner_key.key_value);
        }

        objtype->owner_key = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID;
        token->lock_key    = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID;

        OS_Unlock_Global_Impl(token->obj_type);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("ERROR: cannot unlock global %u for mode %u\n", (unsigned int)token->obj_type,
                 (unsigned int)token->lock_mode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_Unlock_Global:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    /* Keep track of the last successfully-issued object ID of each type */
    osal_id_t last_id_issued;

    /* The number of individual transactions (lock/unlock cycles) on this type */
    uint32 transaction_count;

    /* The key required to unlock this table */
    osal_key_t owner_key;
} OS_objtype_state_t
...
#define OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID ((osal_key_t){0})
...
#define OS_LOCK_KEY_FIXED_VALUE 0x4D000000
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER 0x10
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
OS_DEBUG("ERROR: cannot unlock global %u for mode %u\n", (unsigned int)token->obj_type,
                 (unsigned int)token->lock_mode);
explanation: No direct uses of any of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) appear in the provided OS_Unlock_Global implementation or the related type definitions. The function body consists of integer/enum comparisons, bitmasking operations, structure field assignments, and calls to other functions. The simple assignments and comparisons (e.g. objtype->owner_key = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID; token->lock_key = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID; the key_value mask/comparison) do not involve string handling and therefore do not need investigation under Rule 21.17. Note: the calls to external routines (OS_Unlock_Global_Impl and OS_DEBUG) are outside the provided code; their implementations should be checked separately for any use of the restricted string.h functions, but those implementations are not part of the supplied fragment and thus are not considered direct violations within this function.
